elements.content: Using lactic acid derivatives as chiral ligands, a pair of unprecedented homochiral metal–organic zeolites have been synthesized that feature zeotype CAN topology and have high porosity for enantioselective separation of racemates.
elements.clean_text: Using lactic acid derivatives as chiral ligands, a pair of unprecedented homochiral metal-organic zeolites have been synthesized that feature zeotype CAN topology and have high porosity for enantioselective separation of racemates.

elements.content:
Two homochiral metal−organic zeolites based on lactic acid derivative ligands have been synthesized that have zeotype CAN topology and high porosity for enantioselective separation of racemates.

Currently, homochiral metal–organic frameworks (HMOFs) have been extensively searched because of their promising application in heterogeneous asymmetric catalysis and enantioselective separation. However, HMOFs with enantioselective function should have large accessible pores or channels, allowing for the facile diffusion of substrates. Metal–organic zeolites (MOZs) represent a unique subset of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) that are topologically related to the inorganic zeolites and exhibit similar properties, such as readily accessible extra-large cavities, high surface area, and chemical stability. Thus, homochiral metal–organic zeolites (HMOZs) have an expansive developing foreground in enantioselective processes. Although a large number of MOFs have been obtained in the past several years, the construction and design of HMOZs are still a huge challenge. To date, tremendous efforts have been devoted to obtaining HMOFs and three general approaches have been developed, namely, spontaneous resolution, chiral induction, and the use of enantiopure ligands. Among these synthesis methods, the most promising route to constructing HMOFs is the self-assembly of enantiopure organic ligands with metal ions. Moreover, some groups have successfully used multicarboxylate ligands as building blocks to construct a few porous MOZs. So, using chiral carboxylate compounds as linkers to construct porous HMOZs may be a feasible approach.
elements.clean_text:
Two homochiral metal-organic zeolites based on lactic acid derivative ligands have been synthesized that have zeotype CAN topology and high porosity for enantioselective separation of racemates.

Currently, homochiral metal-organic frameworks (HMOFs) have been extensively searched because of their promising application in heterogeneous asymmetric catalysis and enantioselective separation. However, HMOFs with enantioselective function should have large accessible pores or channels, allowing for the facile diffusion of substrates. Metal-organic zeolites (MOZs) represent a unique subset of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) that are topologically related to the inorganic zeolites and exhibit similar properties, such as readily accessible extra-large cavities, high surface area, and chemical stability. Thus, homochiral metal-organic zeolites (HMOZs) have an expansive developing foreground in enantioselective processes. Although a large number of MOFs have been obtained in the past several years, the construction and design of HMOZs are still a huge challenge. To date, tremendous efforts have been devoted to obtaining HMOFs and three general approaches have been developed, namely, spontaneous resolution, chiral induction, and the use of enantiopure ligands. Among these synthesis methods, the most promising route to constructing HMOFs is the self-assembly of enantiopure organic ligands with metal ions. Moreover, some groups have successfully used multicarboxylate ligands as building blocks to construct a few porous MOZs. So, using chiral carboxylate compounds as linkers to construct porous HMOZs may be a feasible approach.

elements.content: Recently, we have synthesized a pair of enantiopure ligands by modifying lactic acid, which contains three functional groups: two rigid carboxylate groups from the isophthalate unit, the enantiopure lactic acid unit, and an oxygen atom as the ether group (). Among them, three carboxylate groups have multiple coordination modes and the enantiopure lactic acid unit can provide the chiral source for the construction of HMOFs; the oxygen atom of the ether group often participates in building the corresponding HMOFs. Using the pair of ligands with transition metals, we have synthesized a series of HMOFs with intriguing structures and diverse topologies. Encouraged by these successes, we wished to further develop zeolitic HMOFs using these ligands with metal ions.
elements.clean_text: Recently, we have synthesized a pair of enantiopure ligands by modifying lactic acid, which contains three functional groups: two rigid carboxylate groups from the isophthalate unit, the enantiopure lactic acid unit, and an oxygen atom as the ether group (). Among them, three carboxylate groups have multiple coordination modes and the enantiopure lactic acid unit can provide the chiral source for the construction of HMOFs; the oxygen atom of the ether group often participates in building the corresponding HMOFs. Using the pair of ligands with transition metals, we have synthesized a series of HMOFs with intriguing structures and diverse topologies. Encouraged by these successes, we wished to further develop zeolitic HMOFs using these ligands with metal ions.

<title>Corresponding Enantiopure Linkers and the Synthesis
Route of <bold>1-D</bold> and <bold>1-L</bold>

elements.clean_text: 1  Corresponding Enantiopure Linkers and the Synthesis Route of 1-D and 1-L

elements.content: In this work, a pair of unprecedented HMOZs, namely, {[MnIII 1/3MnII 2/3K1/3Na1/3((S)-CIA)]·xG} n (1-L) and {[MnIII 1/3MnII 2/3K1/3Na1/3((R)-CIA)2]·xG} n (1-D), have been synthesized by hydrothermal reactions at 100 °C, respectively. They feature rare CAN-type frameworks with pentanuclear hererometal clusters and a honeycomb channel with a diameter of about 1.2 nm.
elements.clean_text: In this work, a pair of unprecedented HMOZs, namely, {[MnIII 1/3MnII 2/3K1/3Na1/3((S)-CIA)]⋅xG} n  (1-L) and {[MnIII 1/3MnII 2/3K1/3Na1/3((R)-CIA)2]⋅xG} n  (1-D), have been synthesized by hydrothermal reactions at 100 °C, respectively. They feature rare CAN-type frameworks with pentanuclear hererometal clusters and a honeycomb channel with a diameter of about 1.2 nm.

elements.content: X-ray crystallography has revealed that 1-L and 1-D crystallize in the hexagonal space group P63 with Flack parameters of 0.003(4) and 0.001(4), respectively, demonstrating the enantiomeric purity of the single crystals (Table S1). Complexes 1-L and 1-D are enantiomers, so we mainly detail the structure of 1-L. The asymmetric unit in 1-L is composed of one manganese ion, one-third K+ ion, one-third Na+ ion, one-third water molecule, and a deprotonated (S)-CIA ligand. Moreover, some guest molecules in the channels are disordered and cannot be further identified directly; thus, the SQUEEZE method has to be applied for structural refinement.
elements.clean_text: X-ray crystallography has revealed that 1-L and 1-D crystallize in the hexagonal space group P63 with Flack parameters of 0.003(4) and 0.001(4), respectively, demonstrating the enantiomeric purity of the single crystals (Table S1). Complexes 1-L and 1-D are enantiomers, so we mainly detail the structure of 1-L. The asymmetric unit in 1-L is composed of one manganese ion, one-third K+ ion, one-third Na+ ion, one-third water molecule, and a deprotonated (S)-CIA ligand. Moreover, some guest molecules in the channels are disordered and cannot be further identified directly; thus, the SQUEEZE method has to be applied for structural refinement.

elements.content: As shown in a, each (S)-CIA ligand acts as a κ10 linker and connects four manganese, two potassium, and two sodium ions. For the unique coordination modes, a rare pentanuclear cluster with trigonal-bipyramidal geometry is constructed by six carboxylate groups from the isophthalate unit, three lactic acid units, three mnaganese ions, a potassium ion, a sodium ion, and a water molecule (b). In this pentanuclear cluster, considering the charge balance of the framework, all manganese ions should be comprised of Mn3+ and Mn2+ ions according to the ratio of 1:2 (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text: As shown in a, each (S)-CIA ligand acts as a κ10 linker and connects four manganese, two potassium, and two sodium ions. For the unique coordination modes, a rare pentanuclear cluster with trigonal-bipyramidal geometry is constructed by six carboxylate groups from the isophthalate unit, three lactic acid units, three mnaganese ions, a potassium ion, a sodium ion, and a water molecule (b). In this pentanuclear cluster, considering the charge balance of the framework, all manganese ions should be comprised of Mn3+ and Mn2+ ions according to the ratio of 1:2 (Figure S1).

elements.content: (a) Coordination environment in complex 1-L. (b) Pentanuclear hererometal cluster. (c) Pentanuclear clusters linked together by isophthalate units along the c axis in 1-L. (d) Pentanuclear clusters linked together by half of an isophthalate unit and a lactic acid unit along the ab plane in 1-L.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination environment in complex 1-L. (b) Pentanuclear hererometal cluster. (c) Pentanuclear clusters linked together by isophthalate units along the c axis in 1-L. (d) Pentanuclear clusters linked together by half of an isophthalate unit and a lactic acid unit along the ab plane in 1-L.

elements.content: The above pentanuclear clusters are further linked together by three (S)-CIA fragments along the c axis and six (S)-CIA fragments along the ab plane (c,d), resulting in a 3D framework (a). The framework has a 1D honeycomb channel along the c axis, and the width of the channel is up to 12 Å. In order to further simplify the above framework, only the connectivity between (S)-CIA and manganese centers is considered, where the sodium and potassium ions are regarded as counterions. In the structure of 1-L, the six-coordinate manganese center with tetrahedral geometry acts as a 4-connected node (Figure S2). Moreover, every (S)-CIA ligand is also coordinated with four manganese ions, acting as 4-connected nodes (Figure S3). Thus, the whole framework of 1-L is a very rare CAN network with the point symbol of (42.64; b).
elements.clean_text: The above pentanuclear clusters are further linked together by three (S)-CIA fragments along the c axis and six (S)-CIA fragments along the ab plane (c,d), resulting in a 3D framework (a). The framework has a 1D honeycomb channel along the c axis, and the width of the channel is up to 12 Å. In order to further simplify the above framework, only the connectivity between (S)-CIA and manganese centers is considered, where the sodium and potassium ions are regarded as counterions. In the structure of 1-L, the six-coordinate manganese center with tetrahedral geometry acts as a 4-connected node (Figure S2). Moreover, every (S)-CIA ligand is also coordinated with four manganese ions, acting as 4-connected nodes (Figure S3). Thus, the whole framework of 1-L is a very rare CAN network with the point symbol of (42.64; b).

elements.content: Framework of 1-L consisting of a 1D nanochannel (a) and the CAN network in 1-L (b).
elements.clean_text: 2  Framework of 1-L consisting of a 1D nanochannel (a) and the CAN network in 1-L (b).

elements.content: The solid-state circular dichroism (CD) measurements of complexes 1-D and 1-L have been performed to further demonstrate their homochirality (Figure S4). The CD spectrum of complex 1-D exhibits a strong positive CD signal at 293 nm, and that of complex 1-L has a negative CD signal in the same place, revealing that complexes 1-D and 1-L are enantiomers.
elements.clean_text: The solid-state circular dichroism (CD) measurements of complexes 1-D and 1-L have been performed to further demonstrate their homochirality (Figure S4). The CD spectrum of complex 1-D exhibits a strong positive CD signal at 293 nm, and that of complex 1-L has a negative CD signal in the same place, revealing that complexes 1-D and 1-L are enantiomers.

elements.content: 1-L and 1-D are porous frameworks and exhibit solvent-accessible volumes of about 58%, as calculated by PLATON. They are very stable in common organic solvents, such as methanol, ethanol, and so on (Figure S9). However, 1-L and 1-D are soluble in water, which may be attributed to the existence of Na+ and K+ ions. Thermogravimetic analysis (TGA) indicated that the removal of solvent molecules occurred in the temperature range of 40–300 °C (Figure S10). Because 1-L and 1-D are enantiomers, 1-L was only selected for characterization of the porosity. The reversible N2 sorption experiments of 1-L showed a type I isotherm, typical materials having permanent microporosity. The Langmuir and Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface areas are 1845.5 and 1164.0 m2/g, respectively, for 1-L (). Furthermore, 1-L also exhibited a significant uptake capacity for CO2, and the CO2 uptake values are 59.67 cm3/g at 273 K and 56.81 cm3/g at 298 K.
elements.clean_text: 1-L and 1-D are porous frameworks and exhibit solvent-accessible volumes of about 58%, as calculated by PLATON. They are very stable in common organic solvents, such as methanol, ethanol, and so on (Figure S9). However, 1-L and 1-D are soluble in water, which may be attributed to the existence of Na+ and K+ ions. Thermogravimetic analysis (TGA) indicated that the removal of solvent molecules occurred in the temperature range of 40-300 °C (Figure S10). Because 1-L and 1-D are enantiomers, 1-L was only selected for characterization of the porosity. The reversible N2 sorption experiments of 1-L showed a type I isotherm, typical materials having permanent microporosity. The Langmuir and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface areas are 1845.5 and 1164.0 m2/g, respectively, for 1-L (). Furthermore, 1-L also exhibited a significant uptake capacity for CO2, and the CO2 uptake values are 59.67 cm3/g at 273 K and 56.81 cm3/g at 298 K.

elements.content: N2 and CO2 sorption isotherms of 1-L.
elements.clean_text: 3  N2 and CO2 sorption isotherms of 1-L.

elements.content: As a new class of chiral hybrid materials, HMOFs have been attracting attention because of their potential applications in enantioselective separation. To date, some HMOFs have exhibited good chiral separation performance. Although many porous HMOF structures have been reported in the past several years, HMOFs with N2 uptake of >400 cm3/g at 77 K and 1 atm are still scarce. For these reasons, we want to see whether complexes 1-D and 1-L have the capability for enantioselective separation of racemic small molecules. After immersion of 1-D or 1-L into some racemic alcohols, we find that 1-D or 1-L can enantioselectively adsorb (R)-1-phenethyl alcohol or (S)-1-phenethyl alcohol at a medium enantiomeric excess value ( and Figures S12 and S13). The adsorption process may be attributed to interactions among hydroxyl groups (from chiral alcohols) and an oxygen atom (from the water molecule), which make the above chiral molecules dock orderly in the channels.
elements.clean_text: As a new class of chiral hybrid materials, HMOFs have been attracting attention because of their potential applications in enantioselective separation. To date, some HMOFs have exhibited good chiral separation performance. Although many porous HMOF structures have been reported in the past several years, HMOFs with N2 uptake of >400 cm3/g at 77 K and 1 atm are still scarce. For these reasons, we want to see whether complexes 1-D and 1-L have the capability for enantioselective separation of racemic small molecules. After immersion of 1-D or 1-L into some racemic alcohols, we find that 1-D or 1-L can enantioselectively adsorb (R)-1-phenethyl alcohol or (S)-1-phenethyl alcohol at a medium enantiomeric excess value ( and Figures S12 and S13). The adsorption process may be attributed to interactions among hydroxyl groups (from chiral alcohols) and an oxygen atom (from the water molecule), which make the above chiral molecules dock orderly in the channels.

elements.content:
Enantioselective Sorption of <bold>1-D</bold> and <bold>1-L</bold> toward Racemic Methyl Lactate and 1-Phenethyl Alcohol

Determined by chiral gas chromatography (letters in parentheses specify the preferable isomer).

In summary, using predesigned lactic acid derivative ligands [(R)-CIA and (S)-CIA] to assemble with K+, Na+, and Mn2+ and Mn3+ ions, a pair of unprecedented porous HMOZs with CAN topology have been successfully synthesized that can enantioselectively adsorb racemic alcohol and have promising applications in enantioselective separation. This work opens a feasible approach to constructing functional HMOZs through the employment of chiral carboxylate compounds and metal ions.
elements.clean_text: In summary, using predesigned lactic acid derivative ligands [(R)-CIA and (S)-CIA] to assemble with K+, Na+, and Mn2+ and Mn3+ ions, a pair of unprecedented porous HMOZs with CAN topology have been successfully synthesized that can enantioselectively adsorb racemic alcohol and have promising applications in enantioselective separation. This work opens a feasible approach to constructing functional HMOZs through the employment of chiral carboxylate compounds and metal ions.

They are very stable in common organic solvents, such as methanol, ethanol, and so on (Figure S9). However, 1-L and 1-D are soluble in water, which may be attributed to the existence of Na+ and K+ ions. Thermogravimetic analysis (TGA) indicated that the removal of solvent molecules occurred in the temperature range of 40–300 °C (Figure S10). metadata.title:
Synthesis of Metal–Organic Zeolites with Homochirality
and High Porosity for Enantioselective Separation
